title: 110_hr4239
content: The Act may be cited as the "Establishing The House Independent Commission on Standards Act" and establishes the House Ethics Commission. The House Independent Commission on Standards is established within the legislative branch, consisting of 8 members appointed by the Republican and Democratic leaders. Members serve 4-year terms, with initial appointments staggered between 4 and 6 years. The House Independent Commission on Standards consists of 8 members appointed by party leaders, serving 4-year terms with staggered initial appointments. The chairman and vice chairman are chosen at the first meeting. Disqualifications for appointments include restrictions on lobbying and holding incompatible offices. The House Independent Commission on Standards consists of 8 members appointed by party leaders, serving 4-year terms with staggered initial appointments. Members cannot be elected officials or have financial interests in matters before the House. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The House Independent Commission on Standards consists of 8 members appointed by party leaders, serving 4-year terms with staggered initial appointments. Members cannot be elected officials or have financial interests in matters before the House. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings called by the chairman or majority vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is authorized to investigate alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives, report findings and recommendations to the House, issue admonishments, and report to appropriate authorities. The Commission is authorized to investigate alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives and report substantial evidence of violations to Federal or State authorities. It also adopts rules to provide protections to respondents during its procedures. The Commission is authorized to investigate violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives and report evidence to authorities. The Commission, under the authority of the chairman or vice chairman, can hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents. Subpoenas require prior approval from the chairman and ranking minority member of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission can issue subpoenas under the signature of the chairman or vice chairman, and they can be served by designated individuals. Agencies must provide necessary information upon request to the Commission. SEC. 5. PROCEDURAL RULES. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on the official conduct of House members, officers, or employees. Investigations can only be initiated by the Commission upon receipt of a written complaint under oath from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission allows individuals to submit letters requesting investigations into alleged violations by House members, officers, or employees. The Commission can establish procedures for considering these submissions but is not required to take action based on them. The Commission can establish procedures for considering submissions, including a time frame for their consideration. It will not investigate frivolous complaints and will not investigate alleged violations of laws not in effect at the time. Complaints received within 90 days before an election involving a candidate will be delayed until after the election. No information or testimony received, or the contents of a complaint or the fact of its filing, shall be publicly disclosed by any member of the Commission or staff of the Commission unless specifically authorized in each instance by a vote of the Commission. The Commission may appoint a Staff Director and other necessary staff, with the Staff Director appointed jointly by the Speaker and minority leader. The Staff Director's compensation shall not exceed the rate of basic pay for Level III of the Executive Schedule. Commission recommendations will be acted upon accordingly. Upon receipt of a report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives will have it printed in the Congressional Record. Within 14 days of the report being printed, any recommendations for action regarding alleged violations by a Member, officer, or employee of the House will be introduced in the House by the Speaker and minority leader. Resolution introduced by the Speaker and minority leader in the House constitutes a question of privilege under House rules. Members can call it up as a question of privilege after announcing their intention to do so. SEC. 8. AMENDMENTS TO THE RULES OF THE HOUSE REGARDING THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. House Rules Amendments: Clause 3 of rule XI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by striking and redesignating subparagraphs, amending paragraph (b)(1), and striking various paragraphs. Section 803 of the Ethics Reform Act of 1989 is amended by removing subsections (c) and (d). The Act will be effective immediately before noon on January 3, 2009.
